course.subject: ECON
course.name: Macroeconomic and Financial Risk Management
course.description: Macroeconomic and financial risks refer to unexpected changes in macroeconomic conditions or movements in financial variables that would have an adverse effect on the economic profit or investment return of an entity. If the central bank increases interest rates, it reduces profits for firms which rely on debt financing. If a country devalues its currency or defaults on its sovereign debt, foreign creditors or investors realize investment losses. This course introduces fundamental concepts of macroeconomic and financial risk management. It comprises both quantitative and qualitative tools to identify, measure, and manage risks. Challenges in risk management processes are also addressed.
course.prerequisites: (ECON 2103 OR ECON 2113) AND ECON 2123 AND ECON 3334

reviews.author: economist
reviews.title: Beneficial for non-FINA student to gain some derivative knowledge but quite a lot material
reviews.comment_content:
[Long time no write reviews since Year 1 lah]
Caveat: Don't register if you are FINA student as you will waste 2 credits for sure.
1. Foundation of Risk Management (Week 1)
• Identification of Macroeconomic and Financial risks
• Introduction to Risk Measurement and Management tools
• Capital Asset Pricing Model
• Risk-Adjusted Performance Measurement
2. Valuation of Derivative Securities (Weeks 2-3)
• Determination of Forward and Future Prices
• Mechanics and Properties of Options
• Options Pricing: Binomial Model, Black-Scholes-Merton Model, Greek Letters
3. Risk Management Models for Macroeconomic and Financial Risk (Weeks 4-7)
• Value-at-Risk and Stress Testing
• Hedging Strategies Using Futures Contracts
• Risk Metrics and Hedges for Fixed Income Securities
• Managing Foreign Exchange Risk
• Managing Credit Risk
• Managing Operational Risk
• Country and Sovereign Risk Measurement
reviews.comment_teaching:
Nice instructor in UST. I think he is a Hong Konger.
As the class size is very small, you can always ask questions in the chatbox and he will answer at once during the lecture.

The content might be too theoretical as there are not any practical labs for you to apply the knowledge (e.g. using the Bloomberg terminal). Thus, I suggest you should go to Bloomberg by yourself as it is essential in the workplace.
reviews.comment_grading:
Online Class Attendance 10% (easy, right?)
Case Study Analysis 45% (choose ONE from several cases provided, not hard as you can find a lot of references online)
Online Quiz 45% (don't believe in the practice exercise, actual quiz will be 3 times more difficult than that, but you might finish all question though they are wrong lol)

My score
Online Class Attendance 10/10
Case Study Analysis 92/100 (no statistics released)
Online Quiz 32/39 (highest: 32, mean: 25)

Caveat: only 8 people enrolled in this course, so the university grading scheme is not applied here

Letter grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite high for a 2 credit course since the content is too much.
I do little revision every week. And spend a day to prepare for the final quiz.

Prepare your own cheat sheet as you will not have time to go back to lecture notes (though it is an open book quiz). Copy all the formula on the cheat sheet and this might save your grade!

reviews.author: 清香檸檬
reviews.title: A bit boring but much to learn
reviews.comment_content:
Another review has included the details of the topics. I am not going to type them again.

This is a 8-week course with the final quiz on week 9. It is also a small class with only five students this semester.

Comments: Quite a lot for a 2-credit course if you do not have financial mathematics background. Some parts contains a lot of concepts as well, and you have to recite all of them (300+ slides) for the quiz.
reviews.comment_teaching: He teaching is not bad. Prof NG is willing to answer all your questions raise during the lesson. However, honestly his lessons are a little bit boring as he is just reading or sometimes paraphrasing his PPT, which is very very wordy. I think he should make it a lecture "notes" instead and reduce the number of words in the PPT to make the lectures a bit less mundane. All in all, the slides are informative but the classes are not at all interactive.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% attendance, 45% case analysis, 45% "Quiz"

Attendance is taken by his eyes. He does not have any written record in most of the lesson afaik. I showed up in almost all lectures and get 10/10. Tutorials are not necessary.

Case analysis is a 5-paged report on a financial disaster, for example, SocGen trading loss in 2008. The resources given are useful and 2-3 days will be more than sufficient to wrap this up.

The "Quiz" is like a final exam of this course, in the format of 39 MCQs in 2 hrs closed-book. The difficulty is not too high if you have some background in actuarial / financial mathematics. Personally I revised for one whole day only with almost no effort continuously paid during the semester.

My scores: 10+45+?? = A
The quiz score is not revealed.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite low if you a student with some MATH45XX background, and have a bit of prior knowledge about risks.

Just make sure you go to class every lecture, and reserve approx. 2 days for each assessment.
